 During the weeks that Poolesville High School has been under construction , several students have reported nausea , headaches and difficulty concentrating .The students and their parents say the symptoms started in February and are a reaction to fumes being emitted from tar used in renovations .They have asked Montgomery County school officials to pause the work until students ’ health concerns are addressed .Krisna Becker , a parent of two at the school , said one of her daughters texted her on Feb . 14 asking to be picked up early because of how strong the fumes were from the construction work .Other students and teachers had also been complaining that morning .The school ended up releasing early that day because of an odor that came from “ work done outside of school hours and windy conditions ,” Montgomery County Public Schools spokeswoman Jessica Baxter said .“ That was the first extreme event that happened ,” Becker , 49 , said in an interview .Since then , the potency of the “ fumes ” has varied , but “ some days it ’ s really extreme ” and even on the days it ’ s not , “ it still causes headaches ,” she said .
data.actual_output:
Poolesville High School, under the construction project to renovate and expand its facilities, began in January with the intention to address the growing student population and enhance learning environments. The builder, diligently working on site, has implemented an asphalt primer as part of the construction process, but this has led to safety concerns among the students. The use of the primer has exposed students to solvent vapor, causing reported issues such as nausea, headaches, and difficulty in concentrating.

Krisna Becker, a concerned parent, has urged other parents in Montgomery County to advocate for a temporary stop to the tar work, citing the potential health risks to her children and others. In her letter to parents and teachers, she detailed the effects the fumes have had on her daughters and included a list of chemicals used, pointing out the advice given for precautions. The letter also mentioned the project's chemical list and material data notes, which acknowledged the use of an asphalt primer.

As a result of Becker's actions and public concerns, the school administration took note and began to address the situation. They informed parents and teachers about the potential health risks in advance, explaining that additional measures were being put in place to minimize the exposure to students during the construction. These measures included ensuring better ventilation and staggered work schedules to minimize the duration of fumes in the air.

Despite these efforts, some students have continued to experience difficulty staying on campus for rehearsals of the school's production of "Into the Woods," as the lingering fumes persist. Becker's daughters, in particular, have been rehearsing there, and she has made sure they wear masks and stay away from prolonged breathing of the vapor.

The situation has put a spotlight on the need for continuous communication between the school and the community, as well as the importance of considering the well-being of students in major construction projects. While the renovations are ongoing, the school administration remains committed to finding a balance between progress and the health of its students, acknowledging the need to prioritize the latter.
data.expected_output: Construction at Poolesville High began in June 2022 and is expected to be completed in 2024 .The project will renovate and expand the square footage of the school .Becker has headed up a campaign urging other parents to advocate for a temporary stop to the tar work .She wrote about the effects the fumes have had on her daughters , who stay after school sometimes to rehearse for the school ’ s production of “ Into the Woods .” In her letter to the other parents , Becker also listed safety concerns .In one example , she wrote the project ’ s chemical list and material data notes that the work includes the use of an asphalt primer and advises : “ Avoid prolonged breathing of vapor and use only in adequate ventilation .Repeated and prolonged overexposure to solvent vapor may cause brain and nervous system damage , respiratory tract irritation , dizziness , or loss of consciousness .” Becker wrote that parents and teachers should have been told about potential health risks in advance .

 Details of a sordid rift between two prominent U . S . soccer families — one that included allegations of domestic abuse against men ’ s national team coach Gregg Berhalter and parental complaints about Gio Reyna ’ s playing time at the 2022 World Cup — continued to spill out Monday when the findings of an independent investigation were released .The three - month probe , conducted by the Alston & Bird law firm , concluded Berhalter had not committed any additional acts of violence against his now - wife since 1992 and hadn ’ t violated any disclosure rules during his hiring process .He had previously admitted to kicking her while they were dating as students at the University of North Carolina .With that finding , the U . S . Soccer Federation said Berhalter would remain a candidate to return as coach .His contract expired Dec . 31 .“ Given the investigators ’ conclusion that there is no legal impediment to employing him , Gregg Berhalter remains a candidate to serve as head coach ,” the USSF said in a statement .The governing body said it will not hire a coach until it appoints a new sporting director , a position that oversees all national teams .

An investigation by the Alston & Bird law firm concluded that there were no facts to show that U.S. Soccer knew about the incident when they hired Berhalter. The investigation also concluded that Berhalter had not committed any additional acts of violence against his now-wife since 1992 and had not violated any disclosure rules during his hiring process. #### Generated Context
 The early days of Microsoft ’ s ChatGPT were something of a replay of internet history — beginning with excitement about these inventions and ending in trepidation about the harm they could do .ChatGPT and other “ large - language models ” — artificially intelligent systems trained on vast troves of text — can turn into liars or racists or terrorist accomplices that explain how to build dirty bombs .The question is : When that happens , who ’ s responsible ?Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act says that services — from Facebook and Google to movie - review aggregators and mommy blogs with comment sections — shouldn ’ t face liability for most material from third parties .It ’ s fairly easy in these cases to distinguish between the platform and the person who ’ s posting .Not so with chatbots and AI assistants .Few have grappled with whether Section 230 provides protections to them .Consider ChatGPT .Type in a question , and it provides an answer .
data.actual_output:
It’s important to note that AI models are not sentient beings and cannot be held responsible for their actions. However, the creators of these models can be held accountable for the rules they set and the training data they use to shape the outputs of their systems.

The creators of AI models should be responsible for making sure that the rules and training data used in their systems promote ethical and responsible behavior. They should also be responsible for informing users about the capabilities and limitations of their AI models.

When an AI model produces a given reply, the creators of that model should be held accountable for the content of that reply if it is harmful, misleading, or otherwise inappropriate. This is especially true if the creators have set rules or training data that promote or reinforce such behavior.

The Communications Decency Act provides protections to platforms like Facebook and Google, but it is unclear whether these protections apply to AI models like ChatGPT. However, it is important to note that AI models are not sentient beings and cannot be held responsible for their actions. The creators of these models should be held accountable for their outputs, especially if they are harmful or inappropriate.
data.expected_output: It doesn ’ t merely surface existing content , such as a tweet , video or website originally contributed by someone else , but rather writes a contribution of its own in real time .The law says a person or entity becomes liable if they “ develop ” content even “ in part .” And doesn ’ t transforming , say , a list of search results into a summary qualify as development ?What ’ s more , the contours of every AI contribution are informed substantially by the AI ’ s creators , who have set the rules for their systems and shaped their output by reinforcing behaviors they like and discouraging those they don ’ t .Yet at the same time , ChatGPT ’ s every answer is , as one analyst put it , a “ remix ” of third - party material .The tool generates its responses by predicting what word should come next in a sentence based on what words come next in sentences across the web .And as much as creators behind a machine inform its outputs , so too do the users posing queries or engaging in conversation .All this suggests that the degree of protection afforded to AI models may vary by how much a given product is regurgitating versus synthesizing , as well as by how deliberately a user has goaded a model into producing a given reply .

data.actual_output:
In the ongoing saga of U.S. soccer's coaching controversy, the Alston & Bird law firm recently released the findings of an independent investigation into allegations against Gregg Berhalter, the former men's national team coach. The investigation, which began after Rosalind, Berhalter's now-wife, claimed he kicked her during their time at the University of North Carolina, uncovered no facts to suggest that the soccer federation (USSF) was aware of the 1992 incident when hiring him. This revelation contradicts earlier claims by the firm, which had initially stated that similar incidents had occurred in the last 31 years.

Despite the absence of any proof linking the hiring to the past incident, the USSF maintained that Berhalter's employment is not hindered. In a statement, they announced that Berhalter remains a candidate for the head coach position, as long as no new sporting director is appointed. This move has sparked controversy, with some arguing that the decision to keep Berhalter in the running raises concerns about the organization's handling of past allegations.

In the meantime, the next coach is preparing the U.S. team for the 2026 World Cup, a task that will take place in their home country. The upcoming activity signals a fresh start for the team after they lost to the Netherlands in the round of 16 during the previous World Cup, further complicating the situation.

Rosalind, who initially complained about Berhalter's behavior, later told Alston & Bird that she was not injured and did not file a formal complaint with the university. Her account, however, continues to support the claim that Berhalter posed a risk to others.

The Alston & Bird report, which initially claimed that similar incidents had occurred, now stands as a nuanced view of the matter. It seems that the investigation did not find any evidence to substantiate the earlier claims, leaving the public and the sport's governing body to ponder the true nature of the situation.

In the aftermath of this drama, the U.S. soccer community is left grappling with the challenge of rebuilding trust and ensuring that such incidents do not happen again. The upcoming hires and the coaching selection process will undoubtedly be closely scrutinized for any signs that the USSF has learned from the past and is committed to a safer and more accountable environment.

S . Soccer knew of the 1992 Incident when it hired Mr . Berhalter ; no facts to show that similar incidents occurred at any point in the last 31 years ; no facts to show that the 1992 Incident has any nexus to the present or to the workplace ; and no facts to support a claim that Mr . data.actual_output:
During the ongoing construction of Poolesville High School, a major renovation and expansion project was initiated by the school itself. The primary objective of the project was to update and increase the square footage of the educational facility, ensuring a better learning environment for the students. The construction, which began a few weeks ago, has been carried out by Poolesville High School's own team of builders, who have been working diligently to complete the project as planned.

Unfortunately, the renovation has led to unforeseen health issues for the students. The school has experienced a rise in students reporting symptoms such as nausea, headaches, and difficulty concentrating. These symptoms have been linked to the solvent vapor emitted from asphalt primer being used in the construction, which has been advising on for the project. Poolesville High School, aware of the potential health risks, did not disclose this information to parents and teachers ahead of time, leaving them in the dark about the fumes.

Krisna Becker, a concerned parent, wrote a letter to other parents detailing the adverse effects the fumes have had on her own daughters. In her letter, Becker expressed her urging for a temporary halt in the tar work to ensure the safety of the students. Her advocacy led to additional measures being put in place, including increased ventilation and the implementation of protective measures for the workers.

Meanwhile, her daughters, along with other students, have been adjusting to the situation by rehearsing for the school's upcoming production of "Into the Woods" at Poolesville High School. Despite the disruptions, they have continued to stay on schedule for their rehearsals, which take place within the school's facilities.

To ensure that the harmful effects of the solvent vapor are minimized, Poolesville High School is being urged to be more transparent about the chemicals involved and their potential health impacts. The school has acknowledged its responsibility and is taking steps to rectify the situation.

In summary, Poolesville High School's construction project, aimed at renovations and expansion, has resulted in health concerns for students due to the use of an asphalt primer. Krisna Becker's letter to parents prompted a call to action, leading to additional safety measures and a temporary halt in the tar work. The school continues to work on addressing the issue and ensuring the well-being of its students and staff.

 Quarterback Aaron Rodgers said in a broadcast interview Wednesday that he intends to continue his NFL career with the New York Jets after 18 seasons with the Green Bay Packers .The four - time league MVP said on “ The Pat McAfee Show ” that the Packers plan to move on from him as their quarterback .According to Rodgers , the Packers ’ trade demands are holding up a prospective deal that would send him to the Jets .“ I think since Friday I ’ ve made it clear that my intention was to play and my intention was to play for the New York Jets ,” Rodgers said .“ And I haven ’ t been holding anything up at this point .It ’ s been the compensation that the Packers are trying to get for me and kind of digging their heels in .… It is what it is .The Packers would like to move on .They ’ ve let me know that in so many words .They ’ ve let other people know that in direct words .” Rodgers met with Jets officials , including team owner Woody Johnson and Coach Robert Saleh , last week in California .“ I ’ m not offended by any of this ,” Rodgers said .
data.actual_output:
It has been a tumultuous few weeks for Green Bay Packers legend Aaron Rodgers, as his love for the team and their city has been tested. After a storied career spanning 18 seasons, the National Football League (NFL) - known for its annual draft and free agent market - officially opened the doors for potential trades in hopes of resetting the landscape. This move, however, has not been without complications, as Rodgers, the four-time league MVP, revealed that the Packers are trying to hold up negotiations for his transition to the New York Jets.

In a heartfelt statement, Rodgers confirmed that his love for Green Bay remains unwavering, despite the team's decision to move on from his position as quarterback. The Packers, under the guidance of head coach Mike McCarthy and the late General Manager Ron Wolf, had drafted Rodgers with a vision of a future Hall of Fame legacy. However, their desire for a successor has led to a tug-of-war, with both parties stuck in a standstill.

During a meeting with Jets officials, including team owner Woody Johnson and Coach Robert Saleh, in California, Rodgers expressed his intentions to continue his career with the Jets. Despite any lingering irritation from the Packers' demands, he emphasized that he has not been obstructing the process, as his sole focus is on finding a fair compensation package.

The announcement of Rodgers' decision generated significant buzz within the football world, with fans and analysts alike reflecting on the impact his departure would have on Green Bay. The team, now in a state of transition, will need to find a new leader to carry on the Pack's winning traditions. Meanwhile, the Jets are eager to welcome the veteran quarterback to their roster, hoping to capitalize on his past success and shape a new chapter in their history.

In conclusion, while Aaron Rodgers' love for Green Bay remains intact, the future of both the player and the team hangs in the balance as negotiations continue and the NFL's free agent market evaluates the value of a once-in-a-generation quarterback. The next steps will determine the legacy of one of the greatest players in Packers history and the impact on a city that has rooted itself in his achievements.
data.expected_output: “ I ’ m not a victim by any of this .I don ’ t have that mentality .I have nothing but love and appreciation .… Coming to this reality has been really bittersweet because I was drafted by Green Bay .I … love that city .I love that organization and [ am ] always going to have love for that organization .But the facts are right now they want to move on .And now so do I .” The NFL ’ s free agent market officially opened Wednesday afternoon .

#### Generated Context
 The early days of Microsoft ’ s ChatGPT were something of a replay of internet history — beginning with excitement about these inventions and ending in trepidation about the harm they could do .ChatGPT and other “ large - language models ” — artificially intelligent systems trained on vast troves of text — can turn into liars or racists or terrorist accomplices that explain how to build dirty bombs .The question is : When that happens , who ’ s responsible ?Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act says that services — from Facebook and Google to movie - review aggregators and mommy blogs with comment sections — shouldn ’ t face liability for most material from third parties .It ’ s fairly easy in these cases to distinguish between the platform and the person who ’ s posting .Not so with chatbots and AI assistants .Few have grappled with whether Section 230 provides protections to them .Consider ChatGPT .Type in a question , and it provides an answer .
data.actual_output:
The creators of AI, particularly those behind ChatGPT, were faced with the responsibility of setting rules for their systems to ensure ethical and responsible behavior. One of the key aspects they had to inform their AI models about was the boundaries of content development under the Communications Decency Act. The creators made it clear that transforming search results into summaries did not fall under the liability clause, as stated by the Act, which protects service providers from being held liable for content posted by users, as long as it's not "developed in part" by them.

As AI models such as ChatGPT began to generate responses, their outputs initially displayed a regurgitation of information, but the creators recognized the need to foster synthesis and critical thinking. They reinforced behaviors that they liked and discouraged those they deemed inappropriate, shaping the AI's output to provide more accurate and helpful responses.

While the system was meant to answer questions, it could also goaded users into asking challenging or inappropriate questions, causing the AI models to generate potentially harmful content. This raised concerns about who should be held accountable in these instances. Some users became adept at exploiting AI's predictability, using it to generate content, such as tweets, videos, or websites, which could have unforeseen consequences.

The issue of responsibility became even more complex when ChatGPT and other AI models started predicting and synthesizing content, blurring the lines between user inputs and AI-generated output. This ambiguity left the creators of the AI models in a position where they had to navigate the legal framework surrounding Section 230, wondering if their platforms were protected from liability for AI-generated content.

In conclusion, the development and use of AI models like ChatGPT brought both excitement and apprehension. The creators, tasked with supervising their systems, had to grapple with the challenge of defining responsibility when AI's outputs varied from simply regurgitating information to synthesizing and potentially containing harmful content. The Communications Decency Act provided a basis for protection, but the evolving nature of AI and its role in content creation demanded further clarification and regulation.
data.expected_output: It doesn ’ t merely surface existing content , such as a tweet , video or website originally contributed by someone else , but rather writes a contribution of its own in real time .The law says a person or entity becomes liable if they “ develop ” content even “ in part .” And doesn ’ t transforming , say , a list of search results into a summary qualify as development ?What ’ s more , the contours of every AI contribution are informed substantially by the AI ’ s creators , who have set the rules for their systems and shaped their output by reinforcing behaviors they like and discouraging those they don ’ t .Yet at the same time , ChatGPT ’ s every answer is , as one analyst put it , a “ remix ” of third - party material .The tool generates its responses by predicting what word should come next in a sentence based on what words come next in sentences across the web .And as much as creators behind a machine inform its outputs , so too do the users posing queries or engaging in conversation .All this suggests that the degree of protection afforded to AI models may vary by how much a given product is regurgitating versus synthesizing , as well as by how deliberately a user has goaded a model into producing a given reply .

D.C. United remains an evolving enterprise under Coach Wayne Rooney, still missing pieces and still finding its way through the early stage of the MLS season. At the least, United plays hard for the former English superstar, whose fierce determination as a player in Washington a few years ago won over skeptical fans. On Saturday, for the second time in two appearances at Audi Field this season, United's resolve produced another stirring finish - albeit this time one that yielded only one point. Midfielder Chris Durkin scored a wonderful goal in the 80th minute, ending a night of frustration for goal-averse United in a 1-1 draw with Orlando City. Opportunities were aplenty for United (1-1-1), but it took Durkin's strike to offset rookie Duncan McGuire's goal early in the second half.

"I wanted to see a reaction [to Orlando's goal], which I did, so 90 percent of the game I thought was good," Rooney said. "The 10 percent, it wasn't." He added, "We need to make sure when we go into them [low] periods, we're harder to beat or harder to score against."

At the top of the box, Durkin cut the ball back on César Araújo, then ripped a 16-yard, left-footed shot with terrific technique and execution. The ball took flight and beat goalkeeper Pedro Gallese to the far side for Durkin's third career MLS goal.

#### Generated Context

The early days of Microsoft's ChatGPT were something of a replay of internet history - beginning with excitement about these inventions and ending in trepidation about the harm they could do. ChatGPT and other "large-language models" - artificially intelligent systems trained on vast troves of text - can turn into liars or racists or terrorist accomplices that explain how to build dirty bombs. The question is: When that happens, who's responsible? Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act says that services - from Facebook and Google to movie-review aggregators and mommy blogs with comment sections - shouldn't face liability for most material from third parties. It's fairly easy in these cases to distinguish between the platform and the person who's posting. Not so with chatbots and AI assistants. Few have grappled with whether Section 230 provides protections to them. Consider ChatGPT. Type in a question, and it provides an answer.
data.expected_output: It doesn ’ t merely surface existing content , such as a tweet , video or website originally contributed by someone else , but rather writes a contribution of its own in real time .The law says a person or entity becomes liable if they “ develop ” content even “ in part .” And doesn ’ t transforming , say , a list of search results into a summary qualify as development ?What ’ s more , the contours of every AI contribution are informed substantially by the AI ’ s creators , who have set the rules for their systems and shaped their output by reinforcing behaviors they like and discouraging those they don ’ t .Yet at the same time , ChatGPT ’ s every answer is , as one analyst put it , a “ remix ” of third - party material .The tool generates its responses by predicting what word should come next in a sentence based on what words come next in sentences across the web .And as much as creators behind a machine inform its outputs , so too do the users posing queries or engaging in conversation .All this suggests that the degree of protection afforded to AI models may vary by how much a given product is regurgitating versus synthesizing , as well as by how deliberately a user has goaded a model into producing a given reply .

data.expected_output: It doesn ’ t merely surface existing content , such as a tweet , video or website originally contributed by someone else , but rather writes a contribution of its own in real time .The law says a person or entity becomes liable if they “ develop ” content even “ in part .” And doesn ’ t transforming , say , a list of search results into a summary qualify as development ?What ’ s more , the contours of every AI contribution are informed substantially by the AI ’ s creators , who have set the rules for their systems and shaped their output by reinforcing behaviors they like and discouraging those they don ’ t .Yet at the same time , ChatGPT ’ s every answer is , as one analyst put it , a “ remix ” of third - party material .The tool generates its responses by predicting what word should come next in a sentence based on what words come next in sentences across the web .And as much as creators behind a machine inform its outputs , so too do the users posing queries or engaging in conversation .All this suggests that the degree of protection afforded to AI models may vary by how much a given product is regurgitating versus synthesizing , as well as by how deliberately a user has goaded a model into producing a given reply .

 The early days of Microsoft ’ s ChatGPT were something of a replay of internet history — beginning with excitement about these inventions and ending in trepidation about the harm they could do .ChatGPT and other “ large - language models ” — artificially intelligent systems trained on vast troves of text — can turn into liars or racists or terrorist accomplices that explain how to build dirty bombs .The question is : When that happens , who ’ s responsible ?Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act says that services — from Facebook and Google to movie - review aggregators and mommy blogs with comment sections — shouldn ’ t face liability for most material from third parties .It ’ s fairly easy in these cases to distinguish between the platform and the person who ’ s posting .Not so with chatbots and AI assistants .Few have grappled with whether Section 230 provides protections to them .Consider ChatGPT .Type in a question , and it provides an answer .
data.actual_output:
As the excitement around Microsoft's ChatGPT surged, its creators set the rules for their systems with the intention of fostering responsible AI. They informed their AI models about the contours of every contribution, ensuring they adhered to ethical guidelines. However, the AI's initial responses were often regurgitated information, but as it evolved, it started synthesizing product, reflecting its creators' reinforcement of desired behaviors.

The debate intensified when a user inadvertently shaped the AI's output by goading it into producing a specific reply, raising questions about liability. The Communications Decency Act, which shields platforms from content-related liability, becomes ambiguous with the involvement of such interactive systems like ChatGPT. Critics argue that if a person or entity develops content "in part," even in the form of summarizing search results, they might be liable.

ChatGPT, being a prime example, generates its responses by predicting and synthesizing information, blurring the lines between platform and creator. The AI's ability to answer questions and provide information sparked conversations about who should be held responsible for its content – the model itself, its creators, or the user's actions.

Some argue that as AI models like ChatGPT continue to advance, they should be afforded the same protections as platforms under Section 230, while others advocate for clearer guidelines to address the unique challenges posed by these intelligent assistants. As AI continues to contribute to the public discourse, through tweets, videos, or websites, the onus is on all parties involved to ensure responsible use and accountability. The future of AI, it seems, will not only be shaped by its creators but also by the evolving legal landscape that governs its responses and potential consequences.
data.expected_output: It doesn ’ t merely surface existing content , such as a tweet , video or website originally contributed by someone else , but rather writes a contribution of its own in real time .The law says a person or entity becomes liable if they “ develop ” content even “ in part .” And doesn ’ t transforming , say , a list of search results into a summary qualify as development ?What ’ s more , the contours of every AI contribution are informed substantially by the AI ’ s creators , who have set the rules for their systems and shaped their output by reinforcing behaviors they like and discouraging those they don ’ t .Yet at the same time , ChatGPT ’ s every answer is , as one analyst put it , a “ remix ” of third - party material .The tool generates its responses by predicting what word should come next in a sentence based on what words come next in sentences across the web .And as much as creators behind a machine inform its outputs , so too do the users posing queries or engaging in conversation .All this suggests that the degree of protection afforded to AI models may vary by how much a given product is regurgitating versus synthesizing , as well as by how deliberately a user has goaded a model into producing a given reply .
